Utilities Module

class utilities.camera.Camera(width, height)[source]

Represents a camera viewport in a tile-based game world.

The camera tracks a rectangular area of the map in tile units, usually centered on the player or another target. It provides functionality to update its position, convert world coordinates to screen coordinates relative to the camera, and check whether a tile is visible within the camera’s view.

__init__(width, height)[source]

Initialize the Camera object.

Parameters:

  • width (int) – Width of the camera viewport in tiles.

  • height (int) – Height of the camera viewport in tiles.

Parameters:

  • y (int or float) – Y coordinate in world tile units.

Returns:

(x, y) coordinates relative to the camera’s top-left corner.

is_visible(x, y)[source]

Check if a tile at world coordinates (x, y) is currently visible within the camera viewport.

Parameters:

  • x (int or float) – X coordinate in world tile units.

  • y (int or float) – Y coordinate in world tile units.

Returns:

True if the tile is within the camera’s visible area, False otherwise.

Return type:

bool

update(player)[source]

Update the camera position to center on the player. Ensures the camera does not move to negative coordinates.

Parameters:

player (Player) – The player object, expected to have x and y attributes representing position in world tile coordinates (float).

utilities.HitboxUtilities.polygons_collide(poly1, poly2)[source]

Check if two polygons collide using the Separating Axis Theorem (SAT).

SAT states that two convex polygons do not overlap if there exists an axis along which the projections of the two polygons do not overlap.

Parameters:

  • poly1 (list of tuples) – List of (x, y) tuples representing the vertices of the first polygon.

  • poly2 (list of tuples) – List of (x, y) tuples representing the vertices of the second polygon.

Returns:

True if polygons collide (overlap), False otherwise.

Return type:

bool

utilities.pathfinding.a_star_pathfinding(start_x, start_y, goal_x, goal_y, game_map)[source]

A* pathfinding algorithm to find the shortest path from start to goal on a grid map.

Parameters:

  • start_x (float or int) – Starting x coordinate (tile).

  • start_y (float or int) – Starting y coordinate (tile).

  • goal_x (float or int) – Goal x coordinate (tile).

  • goal_y (float or int) – Goal y coordinate (tile).

  • game_map (object) – Map object that must implement is_wall(x, y) method.

Returns:

List of (x, y) tile coordinates representing the path from start to goal.

Returns empty list if no path exists or goal is a wall.

Return type:

list of tuples

utilities.pathfinding.has_line_of_sight(x0, y0, x1, y1, game_map)[source]

Check if there is a clear line of sight between two points on a grid using Bresenham’s line algorithm.

Parameters:

  • x0 (float or int) – Starting x coordinate.

  • y0 (float or int) – Starting y coordinate.

  • x1 (float or int) – Ending x coordinate.

  • y1 (float or int) – Ending y coordinate.

  • game_map (Map) – Map object with method is_wall(x, y) that returns True if position is blocked.

Returns:

True if line of sight exists (no walls between points), False otherwise.

Return type:

bool
